USE OF NATIONAL AVERAGE WAGE INDEX FOR COST-OF-LIVING ADJUSTMENTS. Section 1(f) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust tax tables for inflation by considering the cost-of-living adjustment based on the national average wage index. The national average wage index is calculated as the average index at the end of a 12-month period ending on August 31 of the calendar year. The national average wage index is used to adjust tax tables for inflation in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. - Over $43,050 but not over $104,050: $6,457.50 plus 28% of the excess over $43,050
- Over $104,050 but not over $158,550: $23,537.50 plus 31% of the excess over $104,050
- Over $158,550 but not over $283,150: $40,432.50 plus 36% of the excess over $158,550
- Over $283,150: $85,288.50 plus 39.6% of the excess over $283,150. Heads of Households are also subject to these tax rates. Inflation adjustment for individual alternative minimum tax exemption amounts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include an inflation adjustment for taxable years after 1999, increasing dollar amounts based on the cost-of-living adjustment. If the increase is not a multiple of $50, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50.
